The five health &amp social care measures in today‚Äôs #QueensSpeech today showing our ambitious domestic agenda
Reform the Mental Health Act to improve respect for and care of those receiving mental health treatment (6/6)
Reforms to adult social care to ensure everyone has dignity in old age (5/6)

Our Health Service Safety Investigations Bill establishing a new independent body to help the NHS learn from incidents &amp improve safety (3/6)
A Bill for the #NHSLongTermPlan to bust bureaucracy &amp ensure the NHS has what it needs to care for all for the long term (2/6)

So we must shape the future not fear it. And by doing so we can ensure that technology remains a force for good in the world now and in the years to come (8/8)

But as we have seen this week we‚Äôre not powerless in this digital age We have the power to act to ensure the right online protections are in place especially for those most vulnerable People made this technology and it must be hewn to the benefit of humanity (7/8)
So I agree with Sacks that we‚Äôve got to be on guard for a loss of humanity as we live more of our lives in a virtual world (6/8)
The imperative to make this case was clear this week And it‚Äôs why I‚Äôm glad the big tech companies are now beginning to accept they *must do more to protect us from these harms (5/8)

Just because tech is morally neutral doesn‚Äôt mean we have to be Humanity decency and kindness are *more* not less important in a digitally-connected world It is especially incumbent on supporters of technology to address it (4/8)
But as we‚Äôve seen with the heart-wrenching stories of Molly Russell &amp others the potential for harm especially with the mental health of children is all too prevalent (3/8)
I‚Äôm a massive believer in the immense potential of tech as a force for good In health for example it‚Äôs literally saving lives every day: (2/8)
